bibl.note: The following document is a letter written by E. E. Porter, addressed to his son Edward, on September 19, 1848. The elder Porter writes this letter aboard a steamer in the midst of his travels. He talks about the places he has been and provides Edward with the good news that he may have found a cure for the son's illness.

div1.p: After we left you on the bank at Hanover Landing We had a very Pleasant Trip to Cin on the Ben Franklin The next morning We took a Carrage and went to walnut Hills to Breakfast. I found the Phoenix Landing and would Leave for Memphis the next day (last Thursday) and I thought of going on her but when the Time came for her starting I found She had so much Load on that it was doubtful whether she would be able to get out, as the river is so very Low & I concluded to wait for a smaler Boat or a rise in the river — If I had met the Stephens as I wished I could not have gon home on her as she is now aground below Louisville

I am on a medeum sized stern wheel St Louis Boat which is making a Trip to Memphis as there are so many Passangers & so much Freight for that place — We left Cin 4 P.M yesterday and have been aground 10 Hours on Warsaw Bar but are now under way Just above Carralton— Your mother will wait for more water if it is 3 weeks She has a very pleasant Boarding place
With Mrs Williams the 3d House from Mrs Vails towards the Semanary —

Marys School commenced on Yesterday — She is rather low spirited. I wish she liked her Teachers Better — I have only entered her untill April which will be soon Here and we Hope then all to Meet again — Dear Edward I found on reaching Cin that Dr Mussey had returned from the East and went and consulted with him about your Head and I am Happy in being able to Say that He gives reason to Hope that It can be cured — He Says that He has had 5 or 6 cases and has cured them all — He has given me medicines & Direction which I will send with your Books if The Boat does not stop at Madison Long Enough to get them prepared — You may ask who is Dr Mussey? That you may have confidence so as to carry out his Prescriptions carfully I will say that He perhaps the most successful Physicians & (Especially) Surgans in the United States, Two cases of his opperations we have seen besides He is Pious good man & Pretends to no more than He is Dinner is coming on and I can write no more at this Time — May God Bless you both —
